And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for
Perseus. He is pure air and fire, and the dull
elements of earth and water never appear in him,
but only in patient stillness while his rider mounts
him. He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you
may call beasts.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and
excellent horse.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like
the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance
enforces homage.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: No more, cousin.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from
the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb,
vary deserved praise on my palfrey. It is a theme as
fluent as the sea. Turn the sands into eloquent
tongues, and my horse is argument for them all. ‚ÄôTis
a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a
sovereign‚Äôs sovereign to ride on, and for the world,
familiar to us and unknown, to lay apart their
particular functions and wonder at him. I once writ
a sonnet in his praise and began thus: ‚Äú Wonder of
nature‚Äî‚Äù

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
I have heard a sonnet begin so to one‚Äôs
mistress.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
Then did they imitate that which I composed
to my courser, for my horse is my mistress.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: Your mistress bears well.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
Me well‚Äî which is the prescript praise and
perfection of a good and particular mistress.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress
shrewdly shook your back.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p: So perhaps did yours.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Mine was not bridled.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
O, then belike she was old and gentle, and
you rode like a kern of Ireland, your French hose
off, and in your strait strossers.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and
ride not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have
my horse to my mistress.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his
own hair.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
I could make as true a boast as that if I had
a sow to my mistress.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
‚Äú Le chien est retourn√© √† son propre vomissement,
et la truie lav√©e au bourbier.‚Äù Thou mak‚Äôst use
of anything.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress,
or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

sp.speaker: RAMBURES
sp.p:
My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in
your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Stars, my lord.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p: Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: And yet my sky shall not want.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
That may be, for you bear a many superfluously,
and ‚Äôtwere more honor some were away.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Ev‚Äôn as your horse bears your praises‚Äî
who would trot as well were some of your brags
dismounted.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p:
Would I were able to load him with his
desert! Will it never be day? I will trot tomorrow a
mile, and my way shall be paved with English faces.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
I will not say so for fear I should be faced
out of my way. But I would it were morning, for I
would fain be about the ears of the English.

sp.speaker: RAMBURES
sp.p:
Who will go to hazard with me for twenty
prisoners?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
You must first go yourself to hazard ere you
have them.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p: ‚ÄôTis midnight. I‚Äôll go arm myself.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: The Dauphin longs for morning.

sp.speaker: RAMBURES
sp.p: He longs to eat the English.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: I think he will eat all he kills.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
By the white hand of my lady, he‚Äôs a gallant
prince.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Swear by her foot, that she may tread out
the oath.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
He is simply the most active gentleman of
France.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Doing is activity, and he will still be doing.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: He never did harm, that I heard of.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Nor will do none tomorrow. He will keep
that good name still.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: I know him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
I was told that by one that knows him
better than you.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: What‚Äôs he?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Marry, he told me so himself, and he said
he cared not who knew it.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: He needs not. It is no hidden virtue in him.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
By my faith, sir, but it is; never anybody
saw it but his lackey. ‚ÄôTis a hooded valor, and when
it appears, it will bate.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: Ill will never said well.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
I will cap that proverb with ‚Äú There is
flattery in friendship.‚Äù

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
And I will take up that with ‚Äú Give the devil
his due.‚Äù

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Well placed; there stands your friend for
the devil. Have at the very eye of that proverb with
‚Äú A pox of the devil.‚Äù

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
You are the better at proverbs, by how much
‚Äú A fool‚Äôs bolt is soon shot.‚Äù

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: You have shot over.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: ‚ÄôTis not the first time you were overshot.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p:
My Lord High Constable, the English lie
within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Who hath measured the ground?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p: The Lord Grandpr√©.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
A valiant and most expert gentleman.‚Äî
Would it were day! Alas, poor Harry of England! He
longs not for the dawning as we do.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
What a wretched and peevish fellow is this
King of England to mope with his fat-brained
followers so far out of his knowledge.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
If the English had any apprehension, they
would run away.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
That they lack; for if their heads had any
intellectual armor, they could never wear such
heavy headpieces.

sp.speaker: RAMBURES
sp.p:
That island of England breeds very valiant
creatures. Their mastiffs are of unmatchable
courage.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
Foolish curs, that run winking into the
mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads
crushed like rotten apples. You may as well say
that‚Äôs a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the
lip of a lion.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Just, just; and the men do sympathize with
the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on,
leaving their wits with their wives. And then give
them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they
will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of
beef.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p:
Then shall we find tomorrow they have
only stomachs to eat and none to fight. Now is it
time to arm. Come, shall we about it?

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p:
It is now two o‚Äôclock. But, let me see, by ten
We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Now entertain conjecture of a time
When creeping murmur and the poring dark
Fills the wide vessel of the universe.
From camp to camp, through the foul womb of night,
The hum of either army stilly sounds,
That the fixed sentinels almost receive
The secret whispers of each other‚Äôs watch.
Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames
Each battle sees the other‚Äôs umbered face;
Steed threatens steed in high and boastful neighs
Piercing the night‚Äôs dull ear; and from the tents
The armorers, accomplishing the knights,
With busy hammers closing rivets up,
Give dreadful note of preparation.
The country cocks do crow, the clocks do toll,
And, the third hour of drowsy morning named,
Proud of their numbers and secure in soul,
The confident and overlusty French
Do the low-rated English play at dice
And chide the cripple, tardy-gaited night,
Who like a foul and ugly witch doth limp
So tediously away. The poor condemn√®d English,
Like sacrifices, by their watchful fires
Sit patiently and inly ruminate
The morning‚Äôs danger; and their gesture sad,
Investing lank-lean cheeks and war-worn coats,
Presenteth them unto the gazing moon
So many horrid ghosts. O now, who will behold
The royal captain of this ruined band
Walking from watch to watch, from tent to tent,
Let him cry, ‚Äú Praise and glory on his head!‚Äù
For forth he goes and visits all his host,
Bids them good morrow with a modest smile,
And calls them brothers, friends, and countrymen.
Upon his royal face there is no note
How dread an army hath enrounded him,
Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color
Unto the weary and all-watch√®d night,
But freshly looks and overbears attaint
With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty,
That every wretch, pining and pale before,
Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks.
A largesse universal, like the sun,
His liberal eye doth give to everyone,
Thawing cold fear, that mean and gentle all
Behold, as may unworthiness define,
A little touch of Harry in the night.
And so our scene must to the battle fly,
Where, O for pity, we shall much disgrace,
With four or five most vile and ragged foils
Right ill-disposed in brawl ridiculous,
The name of Agincourt. Yet sit and see,
Minding true things by what their mock‚Äôries be.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the King of England, Bedford, and Gloucester.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Gloucester, ‚Äôtis true that we are in great danger.
The greater therefore should our courage be.‚Äî
Good morrow, brother Bedford. God almighty,
There is some soul of goodness in things evil,
Would men observingly distill it out.
For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers,
Which is both healthful and good husbandry.
Besides, they are our outward consciences
And preachers to us all, admonishing
That we should dress us fairly for our end.
Thus may we gather honey from the weed
And make a moral of the devil himself.
Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.
A good soft pillow for that good white head
Were better than a churlish turf of France.

sp.speaker: ERPINGHAM
sp.l: Not so, my liege, this lodging likes me better,
Since I may say ‚Äú Now lie I like a king.‚Äù

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: ‚ÄôTis good for men to love their present pains
Upon example. So the spirit is eased;
And when the mind is quickened, out of doubt,
The organs, though defunct and dead before,
Break up their drowsy grave and newly move
With casted slough and fresh legerity.
Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas.
Brothers both,
Commend me to the princes in our camp,
Do my good morrow to them, and anon
Desire them all to my pavilion.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: We shall, my liege.

sp.speaker: ERPINGHAM
sp.l: Shall I attend your Grace?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: No, my good knight.
Go with my brothers to my lords of England.
I and my bosom must debate awhile,
And then I would no other company.

sp.speaker: ERPINGHAM
sp.l: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: God-a-mercy, old heart, thou speak‚Äôst cheerfully.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Qui vous l√†?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Discuss unto me: art thou officer or art thou
base, common, and popular?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: I am a gentleman of a company.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Trail‚Äôst thou the puissant pike?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Even so. What are you?

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: As good a gentleman as the Emperor.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Then you are a better than the King.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
The King‚Äôs a bawcock and a heart of gold, a lad
of life, an imp of fame, of parents good, of fist most
valiant. I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heartstring I
love the lovely bully. What is thy name?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Harry le Roy.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Le Roy? A Cornish name. Art thou of Cornish
crew?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: No, I am a Welshman.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Know‚Äôst thou Fluellen?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Tell him I‚Äôll knock his leek about his pate upon
Saint Davy‚Äôs day.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Do not you wear your dagger in your cap
that day, lest he knock that about yours.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Art thou his friend?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: And his kinsman too.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: The figo for thee then!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: I thank you. God be with you.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: My name is Pistol called.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: It sorts well with your fierceness.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: Captain Fluellen.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
So. In the name of Jesu Christ, speak fewer.
It is the greatest admiration in the universal world
when the true and aunchient prerogatifes and
laws of the wars is not kept. If you would take the
pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the
Great, you shall find, I warrant you, that there is
no tiddle taddle nor pibble babble in Pompey‚Äôs
camp. I warrant you, you shall find the ceremonies
of the wars and the cares of it and the forms
of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to
be otherwise.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
Why, the enemy is loud. You hear him all
night.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating
coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also,
look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating
coxcomb, in your own conscience now?

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: I will speak lower.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: I pray you and beseech you that you will.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Though it appear a little out of fashion,
There is much care and valor in this Welshman.

div.stage: Enter three Soldiers, John Bates, Alexander Court, and Michael Williams.

sp.speaker: COURT
sp.p:
Brother John Bates, is not that the morning
which breaks yonder?

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
I think it be, but we have no great cause to desire
the approach of day.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
We see yonder the beginning of the day, but
I think we shall never see the end of it.‚Äî Who goes
there?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Under what captain serve you?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
A good old commander and a most kind
gentleman. I pray you, what thinks he of our
estate?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Even as men wracked upon a sand, that
look to be washed off the next tide.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p: He hath not told his thought to the King?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
No. Nor it is not meet he should, for,
though I speak it to you, I think the King is but a
man as I am. The violet smells to him as it doth to
me. The element shows to him as it doth to me. All
his senses have but human conditions. His ceremonies
laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man,
and though his affections are higher mounted than
ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like
wing. Therefore, when he sees reason of fears as we
do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish as
ours are. Yet, in reason, no man should possess him
with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing it,
should dishearten his army.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
He may show what outward courage he will,
but I believe, as cold a night as ‚Äôtis, he could wish
himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would
he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were
quit here.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
By my troth, I will speak my conscience
of the King. I think he would not wish himself
anywhere but where he is.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
Then I would he were here alone; so should he
be sure to be ransomed, and a many poor men‚Äôs
lives saved.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
I dare say you love him not so ill to wish
him here alone, howsoever you speak this to feel
other men‚Äôs minds. Methinks I could not die anywhere
so contented as in the King‚Äôs company, his
cause being just and his quarrel honorable.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: That‚Äôs more than we know.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
Ay, or more than we should seek after, for we
know enough if we know we are the King‚Äôs subjects.
If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the
King wipes the crime of it out of us.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
But if the cause be not good, the King
himself hath a heavy reckoning to make, when all
those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a
battle, shall join together at the latter day, and cry
all ‚Äú We died at such a place,‚Äù some swearing, some
crying for a surgeon, some upon their wives left
poor behind them, some upon the debts they owe,
some upon their children rawly left. I am afeard
there are few die well that die in a battle, for how
can they charitably dispose of anything when blood
is their argument? Now, if these men do not die
well, it will be a black matter for the king that led
them to it, who to disobey were against all proportion
of subjection.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
So, if a son that is by his father sent about
merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon the sea,
the imputation of his wickedness, by your rule,
should be imposed upon his father that sent him.
Or if a servant, under his master‚Äôs command transporting
a sum of money, be assailed by robbers and
die in many irreconciled iniquities, you may call the
business of the master the author of the servant‚Äôs
damnation. But this is not so. The King is not bound
to answer the particular endings of his soldiers, the
father of his son, nor the master of his servant, for
they purpose not their death when they purpose
their services. Besides, there is no king, be his cause
never so spotless, if it come to the arbitrament of
swords, can try it out with all unspotted soldiers.
Some, peradventure, have on them the guilt of
premeditated and contrived murder; some, of beguiling
virgins with the broken seals of perjury;
some, making the wars their bulwark, that have
before gored the gentle bosom of peace with pillage
and robbery. Now, if these men have defeated the
law and outrun native punishment, though they can
outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.
War is His beadle, war is His vengeance, so that here
men are punished for before-breach of the King‚Äôs
laws in now the King‚Äôs quarrel. Where they feared
the death, they have borne life away; and where they
would be safe, they perish. Then, if they die unprovided,
no more is the King guilty of their damnation
than he was before guilty of those impieties for the
which they are now visited. Every subject‚Äôs duty is
the King‚Äôs, but every subject‚Äôs soul is his own.
Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as
every sick man in his bed: wash every mote out of
his conscience. And, dying so, death is to him
advantage; or not dying, the time was blessedly lost
wherein such preparation was gained. And in him
that escapes, it were not sin to think that, making
God so free an offer, He let him outlive that day to
see His greatness and to teach others how they
should prepare.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
‚ÄôTis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill
upon his own head; the King is not to answer it.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet
I determine to fight lustily for him.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
I myself heard the King say he would not
be ransomed.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
Ay, he said so to make us fight cheerfully,
but when our throats are cut, he may be ransomed
and we ne‚Äôer the wiser.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
If I live to see it, I will never trust his
word after.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
You pay him then. That‚Äôs a perilous shot out
of an elder gun, that a poor and a private displeasure
can do against a monarch. You may as well go
about to turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face
with a peacock‚Äôs feather. You‚Äôll ‚Äú never trust his
word after.‚Äù Come, ‚Äôtis a foolish saying.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Your reproof is something too round. I
should be angry with you if the time were
convenient.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: I embrace it.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: How shall I know thee again?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear
it in my bonnet. Then, if ever thou dar‚Äôst acknowledge
it, I will make it my quarrel.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Here‚Äôs my glove. Give me another of thine.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
This will I also wear in my cap. If ever thou
come to me and say, after tomorrow, ‚Äú This is my
glove,‚Äù by this hand I will take thee a box on the
ear.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Thou dar‚Äôst as well be hanged.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Well, I will do it, though I take thee in the
King‚Äôs company.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Keep thy word. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: BATES
sp.p:
Be friends, you English fools, be friends. We
have French quarrels enough, if you could tell how
to reckon.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Indeed, the French may lay twenty
French crowns to one they will beat us, for they
bear them on their shoulders. But it is no English
treason to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the
King himself will be a clipper.

Upon the King! Let us our lives, our souls, our
debts, our careful wives, our children, and our sins,
lay on the King!
sp.l: We must bear all. O hard condition,
Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath
Of every fool whose sense no more can feel
But his own wringing. What infinite heart‚Äôs ease
Must kings neglect that private men enjoy?
And what have kings that privates have not too,
Save ceremony, save general ceremony?
And what art thou, thou idol ceremony?
What kind of god art thou that suffer‚Äôst more
Of mortal griefs than do thy worshipers?
What are thy rents? What are thy comings-in?
O ceremony, show me but thy worth!
What is thy soul of adoration?
Art thou aught else but place, degree, and form,
Creating awe and fear in other men,
Wherein thou art less happy, being feared,
Than they in fearing?
What drink‚Äôst thou oft, instead of homage sweet,
But poisoned flattery? O, be sick, great greatness,
And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!
Think‚Äôst thou the fiery fever will go out
With titles blown from adulation?
Will it give place to flexure and low bending?
Canst thou, when thou command‚Äôst the beggar‚Äôs knee,
Command the health of it? No, thou proud dream,
That play‚Äôst so subtly with a king‚Äôs repose.
I am a king that find thee, and I know
‚ÄôTis not the balm, the scepter, and the ball,
The sword, the mace, the crown imperial,
The intertissued robe of gold and pearl,
The farc√®d title running ‚Äôfore the King,
The throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp
That beats upon the high shore of this world;
No, not all these, thrice-gorgeous ceremony,
Not all these, laid in bed majestical,
Can sleep so soundly as the wretched slave
Who, with a body filled and vacant mind,
Gets him to rest, crammed with distressful bread;
Never sees horrid night, the child of hell,
But, like a lackey, from the rise to set
Sweats in the eye of Phoebus, and all night
Sleeps in Elysium; next day after dawn
Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse,
And follows so the ever-running year
With profitable labor to his grave.
And, but for ceremony, such a wretch,
Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep,
Had the forehand and vantage of a king.
The slave, a member of the country‚Äôs peace,
Enjoys it, but in gross brain little wots
What watch the King keeps to maintain the peace,
Whose hours the peasant best advantages.

sp.speaker: ERPINGHAM
sp.l: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence,
Seek through your camp to find you.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Good old knight,
Collect them all together at my tent.
I‚Äôll be before thee.

sp.speaker: ERPINGHAM
sp.l: I shall do ‚Äôt, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: O God of battles, steel my soldiers‚Äô hearts.
Possess them not with fear. Take from them now
The sense of reck‚Äôning or th‚Äô oppos√®d numbers
Pluck their hearts from them. Not today, O Lord,
O, not today, think not upon the fault
My father made in compassing the crown.
I Richard‚Äôs body have interr√®d new
And on it have bestowed more contrite tears
Than from it issued forc√®d drops of blood.
Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay
Who twice a day their withered hands hold up
Toward heaven to pardon blood. And I have built
Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests
Sing still for Richard‚Äôs soul. More will I do‚Äî
Though all that I can do is nothing worth,
Since that my penitence comes after all,
Imploring pardon.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: My liege.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My brother Gloucester‚Äôs voice.‚Äî Ay,
I know thy errand. I will go with thee.
The day, my friends, and all things stay for me.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter the Dauphin, Orl√©ans, Rambures, and Beaumont.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.l: The sun doth gild our armor. Up, my lords.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.l: Montez √† cheval! My horse, varlet! Lackey! Ha!

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: O brave spirit!

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p: Via les eaux et terre.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.p: Rien puis? L‚Äôair et feu?

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.p: Cieux, cousin Orl√©ans.
Now, my Lord Constable?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: Hark how our steeds for present service neigh.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.l: Mount them, and make incision in their hides,
That their hot blood may spin in English eyes
And dout them with superfluous courage. Ha!

sp.speaker: RAMBURES
sp.l: What, will you have them weep our horses‚Äô blood?
How shall we then behold their natural tears?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The English are embattled, you French peers.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: To horse, you gallant princes, straight to horse.
Do but behold yond poor and starv√®d band,
And your fair show shall suck away their souls,
Leaving them but the shales and husks of men.
There is not work enough for all our hands,
Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins
To give each naked curtal ax a stain,
That our French gallants shall today draw out
And sheathe for lack of sport. Let us but blow on them,
The vapor of our valor will o‚Äôerturn them.
‚ÄôTis positive against all exceptions, lords,
That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants,
Who in unnecessary action swarm
About our squares of battle, were enough
To purge this field of such a hilding foe,
Though we upon this mountain‚Äôs basis by
Took stand for idle speculation,
But that our honors must not. What‚Äôs to say?
A very little little let us do,
And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound
The tucket sonance and the note to mount,
For our approach shall so much dare the field
That England shall couch down in fear and yield.

sp.speaker: GRANDPR√â
sp.l: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?
Yond island carrions, desperate of their bones,
Ill-favoredly become the morning field.
Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose,
And our air shakes them passing scornfully.
Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host
And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps.
The horsemen sit like fix√®d candlesticks
With torch staves in their hand, and their poor jades
Lob down their heads, drooping the hides and hips,
The gum down-roping from their pale dead eyes,
And in their pale dull mouths the gemeled bit
Lies foul with chawed grass, still and motionless.
And their executors, the knavish crows,
Fly o‚Äôer them all, impatient for their hour.
Description cannot suit itself in words
To demonstrate the life of such a battle
In life so lifeless, as it shows itself.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.l: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits,
And give their fasting horses provender,
And after fight with them?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: I stay but for my guard. On, to the field!
I will the banner from a trumpet take
And use it for my haste. Come, come away.
The sun is high, and we outwear the day.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Gloucester, Bedford, Exeter, Erpingham with all his host, Salisbury, and Westmoreland.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: The King himself is rode to view their battle.

sp.speaker: WESTMORELAND
sp.l: Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: There‚Äôs five to one. Besides, they all are fresh.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: God‚Äôs arm strike with us! ‚ÄôTis a fearful odds.
God be wi‚Äô you, princes all. I‚Äôll to my charge.
If we no more meet till we meet in heaven,
Then joyfully, my noble Lord of Bedford,
My dear Lord Gloucester, and my good Lord Exeter,
And my kind kinsman, warriors all, adieu.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Farewell, good Salisbury, and good luck go with thee.
And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it,
For thou art framed of the firm truth of valor.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Farewell, kind lord. Fight valiantly today.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: He is as full of valor as of kindness,
Princely in both.

sp.speaker: WESTMORELAND
sp.l: O, that we now had here
But one ten thousand of those men in England
That do no work today.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: What‚Äôs he that wishes so?
My cousin Westmoreland? No, my fair cousin.
If we are marked to die, we are enough
To do our country loss; and if to live,
The fewer men, the greater share of honor.
God‚Äôs will, I pray thee wish not one man more.
By Jove, I am not covetous for gold,
Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost;
It yearns me not if men my garments wear;
Such outward things dwell not in my desires.
But if it be a sin to covet honor,
I am the most offending soul alive.
No, ‚Äôfaith, my coz, wish not a man from England.
God‚Äôs peace, I would not lose so great an honor
As one man more, methinks, would share from me,
For the best hope I have. O, do not wish one more!
Rather proclaim it, Westmoreland, through my host,
That he which hath no stomach to this fight,
Let him depart. His passport shall be made,
And crowns for convoy put into his purse.
We would not die in that man‚Äôs company
That fears his fellowship to die with us.
This day is called the feast of Crispian.
He that outlives this day and comes safe home
Will stand o‚Äô tiptoe when this day is named
And rouse him at the name of Crispian.
He that shall see this day, and live old age,
Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors
And say ‚Äú Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.‚Äù
Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars.
Old men forget; yet all shall be forgot,
But he‚Äôll remember with advantages
What feats he did that day. Then shall our names,
Familiar in his mouth as household words,
Harry the King, Bedford and Exeter,
Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester,
Be in their flowing cups freshly remembered.
This story shall the good man teach his son,
And Crispin Crispian shall ne‚Äôer go by,
From this day to the ending of the world,
But we in it shall be remember√®d‚Äî
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;
For he today that sheds his blood with me
Shall be my brother; be he ne‚Äôer so vile,
This day shall gentle his condition;
And gentlemen in England now abed
Shall think themselves accursed they were not here,
And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks
That fought with us upon Saint Crispin‚Äôs day.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed.
The French are bravely in their battles set,
And will with all expedience charge on us.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: All things are ready if our minds be so.

sp.speaker: WESTMORELAND
sp.l: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?

sp.speaker: WESTMORELAND
sp.l: God‚Äôs will, my liege, would you and I alone,
Without more help, could fight this royal battle!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Why, now thou hast unwished five thousand men,
Which likes me better than to wish us one.‚Äî
You know your places. God be with you all.

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: Once more I come to know of thee, King Harry,
If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound,
Before thy most assur√®d overthrow.
For certainly thou art so near the gulf
Thou needs must be englutted. Besides, in mercy,
The Constable desires thee thou wilt mind
Thy followers of repentance, that their souls
May make a peaceful and a sweet retire
From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies
Must lie and fester.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Who hath sent thee now?

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: The Constable of France.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I pray thee bear my former answer back.
Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.
Good God, why should they mock poor fellows thus?
The man that once did sell the lion‚Äôs skin
While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.
A many of our bodies shall no doubt
Find native graves, upon the which, I trust,
Shall witness live in brass of this day‚Äôs work.
And those that leave their valiant bones in France,
Dying like men, though buried in your dunghills,
They shall be famed; for there the sun shall greet them
And draw their honors reeking up to heaven,
Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime,
The smell whereof shall breed a plague in France.
Mark, then, abounding valor in our English,
That being dead, like to the bullet‚Äôs crazing,
Break out into a second course of mischief,
Killing in relapse of mortality.
Let me speak proudly: tell the Constable
We are but warriors for the working day;
Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched
With rainy marching in the painful field.
There‚Äôs not a piece of feather in our host‚Äî
Good argument, I hope, we will not fly‚Äî
And time hath worn us into slovenry.
But, by the Mass, our hearts are in the trim,
And my poor soldiers tell me, yet ere night
They‚Äôll be in fresher robes, or they will pluck
The gay new coats o‚Äôer the French soldiers‚Äô heads
And turn them out of service. If they do this,
As, if God please, they shall, my ransom then
Will soon be levied. Herald, save thou thy labor.
Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald.
They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints,
Which, if they have, as I will leave ‚Äôem them,
Shall yield them little, tell the Constable.

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: I shall, King Harry. And so fare thee well.
Thou never shalt hear herald anymore.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
I fear thou wilt once more come again
for a ransom.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: My lord, most humbly on my knee I beg
The leading of the vaward.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Take it, brave York.
Now, soldiers, march away,
And how Thou pleasest, God, dispose the day.

stage.stage: Enter Pistol, French Soldier, and Boy.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Yield, cur.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p:
Je pense que vous √™tes le gentilhomme
de bonne qualit√©.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Qualtitie calmie custure me. Art thou a gentleman?
What is thy name? Discuss.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p: √î Seigneur Dieu!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
O, Seigneur Dew should be a gentleman. Perpend
my words, O Seigneur Dew, and mark: O
Seigneur Dew, thou diest on point of fox, except, O
Seigneur, thou do give to me egregious ransom.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p:
√î, prenez mis√©ricorde! Ayez piti√© de
moi!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Moy shall not serve. I will have forty moys, or
I will fetch thy rim out at thy throat in drops of
crimson blood.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p:
Est-il impossible d‚Äô√©chapper la force
de ton bras?

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Brass, cur? Thou damned and luxurious
mountain goat, offer‚Äôst me brass?

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p: √î, pardonnez-moi!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Say‚Äôst thou me so? Is that a ton of moys?‚Äî
Come hither, boy. Ask me this slave in French what
is his name.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: √âcoutez. Comment √™tes-vous appel√©?

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p: Monsieur le Fer.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: He says his name is Master Fer.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Master Fer. I‚Äôll fer him, and firk him, and ferret
him. Discuss the same in French unto him.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
I do not know the French for ‚Äú fer,‚Äù and ‚Äú ferret,‚Äù
and ‚Äú firk.‚Äù

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Bid him prepare, for I will cut his throat.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p: Que dit-il, monsieur?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Il me commande √† vous dire que vous faites vous
pr√™t, car ce soldat ici est dispos√© tout √† cette heure de
couper votre gorge.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Owy, cuppele gorge, permafoy, peasant, unless
thou give me crowns, brave crowns, or mangled
shalt thou be by this my sword.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p:
√î, je vous supplie, pour l‚Äôamour de
Dieu, me pardonner. Je suis le gentilhomme de bonne
maison. Gardez ma vie, et je vous donnerai deux
cents √©cus.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: What are his words?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
He prays you to save his life. He is a gentleman of a
good house, and for his ransom he will give you two
hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns
will take.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p: Petit monsieur, que dit-il?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Encore qu‚Äôil est contre son jurement de pardonner
aucun prisonnier; n√©anmoins, pour les √©cus que vous
lui avez promis, il est content √† vous donner la libert√©,
le franchisement.

sp.speaker: FRENCH SOLDIER
sp.p:
Sur mes genoux je vous donne mille
remerc√Æments, et je m‚Äôestime heureux que j‚Äôai tomb√©
entre les mains d‚Äôun chevalier, je pense, le plus brave,
vaillant, et tr√®s distingu√© seigneur d‚ÄôAngleterre.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Expound unto me, boy.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks,
and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall‚Äôn
into the hands of one, as he thinks, the most
brave, valorous, and thrice-worthy seigneur of
England.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
As I suck blood, I will some mercy show.
Follow me.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Suivez-vous le grand capitaine.
sp.stage: The French Soldier stands up. He and Pistol exit.
sp.p:
I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty
a heart. But the saying is true: ‚Äú The empty vessel
makes the greatest sound.‚Äù Bardolph and Nym had
ten times more valor than this roaring devil i‚Äô th‚Äô old
play, that everyone may pare his nails with a wooden
dagger, and they are both hanged, and so would
this be if he durst steal anything adventurously. I
must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our
camp. The French might have a good prey of us if he
knew of it, for there is none to guard it but boys.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Constable, Orl√©ans, Bourbon, Dauphin, and Rambures.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: √î diable!

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.l: √î Seigneur! Le jour est perdu, tout est perdu!

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.l: Mort de ma vie, all is confounded, all!
Reproach and everlasting shame
Sits mocking in our plumes.
√î m√©chante Fortune!
Do not run away.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: Why, all our ranks are broke.

sp.speaker: DAUPHIN
sp.l: O perdurable shame! Let‚Äôs stab ourselves.
Be these the wretches that we played at dice for?

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.l: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?

sp.speaker: BOURBON
sp.l: Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame!
Let us die. In once more! Back again!
And he that will not follow Bourbon now,
Let him go hence, and with his cap in hand
Like a base pander hold the chamber door,
Whilst by a slave, no gentler than my dog,
His fairest daughter is contaminate.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.l: Disorder, that hath spoiled us, friend us now.
Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.

sp.speaker: ORL√âANS
sp.l: We are enough yet living in the field
To smother up the English in our throngs,
If any order might be thought upon.

sp.speaker: BOURBON
sp.l: The devil take order now! I‚Äôll to the throng.
Let life be short, else shame will be too long.

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: Alarum. Enter the King of England and his train, with prisoners.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Well have we done, thrice-valiant countrymen,
But all‚Äôs not done. Yet keep the French the field.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: The Duke of York commends him to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Lives he, good uncle? Thrice within this hour
I saw him down, thrice up again and fighting.
From helmet to the spur, all blood he was.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: In which array, brave soldier, doth he lie,
Larding the plain, and by his bloody side,
Yoke-fellow to his honor-owing wounds,
The noble Earl of Suffolk also lies.
Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over,
Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped,
And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes
That bloodily did yawn upon his face.
He cries aloud ‚Äú Tarry, my cousin Suffolk.
My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.
Tarry, sweet soul, for mine; then fly abreast,
As in this glorious and well-foughten field
We kept together in our chivalry.‚Äù
Upon these words I came and cheered him up.
He smiled me in the face, raught me his hand,
And with a feeble grip, says ‚Äú Dear my lord,
Commend my service to my sovereign.‚Äù
So did he turn, and over Suffolk‚Äôs neck
He threw his wounded arm and kissed his lips,
And so, espoused to death, with blood he sealed
A testament of noble-ending love.
The pretty and sweet manner of it forced
Those waters from me which I would have stopped,
But I had not so much of man in me,
And all my mother came into mine eyes
And gave me up to tears.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I blame you not,
For, hearing this, I must perforce compound
With my full eyes, or they will issue too.
But hark, what new alarum is this same?
The French have reinforced their scattered men.
Then every soldier kill his prisoners.
Give the word through.

div.head: Scene 7

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Kill the poys and the luggage! ‚ÄôTis expressly
against the law of arms. ‚ÄôTis as arrant a piece of
knavery, mark you now, as can be offert, in your
conscience now, is it not?

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
‚ÄôTis certain there‚Äôs not a boy left alive, and
the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha‚Äô
done this slaughter. Besides, they have burned
and carried away all that was in the King‚Äôs tent,
wherefore the King, most worthily, hath caused
every soldier to cut his prisoner‚Äôs throat. O, ‚Äôtis a
gallant king!

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain
Gower. What call you the town‚Äôs name where
Alexander the Pig was born?

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Why, I pray you, is not ‚Äú pig‚Äù great? The pig,
or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the
magnanimous, are all one reckonings, save the
phrase is a little variations.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I
take it.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is
porn. I tell you, captain, if you look in the maps of
the ‚Äôorld, I warrant you sall find, in the comparisons
between Macedon and Monmouth, that the
situations, look you, is both alike. There is a river in
Macedon, and there is also, moreover, a river at
Monmouth. It is called Wye at Monmouth, but it is
out of my prains what is the name of the other river.
But ‚Äôtis all one; ‚Äôtis alike as my fingers is to my
fingers, and there is salmons in both. If you mark
Alexander‚Äôs life well, Harry of Monmouth‚Äôs life is
come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in
all things. Alexander, God knows and you know, in
his rages and his furies and his wraths and his
cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his
indignations, and also being a little intoxicates in
his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, look you,
kill his best friend, Cleitus.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
Our king is not like him in that. He never
killed any of his friends.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
It is not well done, mark you now, to take
the tales out of my mouth ere it is made and
finished. I speak but in the figures and comparisons
of it. As Alexander killed his friend Cleitus, being in
his ales and his cups, so also Harry Monmouth,
being in his right wits and his good judgments,
turned away the fat knight with the great-belly
doublet; he was full of jests and gipes and knaveries
and mocks‚Äî I have forgot his name.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: Sir John Falstaff.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
That is he. I‚Äôll tell you, there is good men
porn at Monmouth.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: Here comes his Majesty.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter King Harry, Exeter, Warwick, Gloucester, Heralds and Bourbon with other prisoners. Flourish.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I was not angry since I came to France
Until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald.
Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill.
If they will fight with us, bid them come down,
Or void the field. They do offend our sight.
If they‚Äôll do neither, we will come to them
And make them skirr away as swift as stones
Enforc√®d from the old Assyrian slings.
Besides, we‚Äôll cut the throats of those we have,
And not a man of them that we shall take
Shall taste our mercy. Go and tell them so.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: How now, what means this, herald? Know‚Äôst thou not
That I have fined these bones of mine for ransom?
Com‚Äôst thou again for ransom?

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: No, great king.
I come to thee for charitable license,
That we may wander o‚Äôer this bloody field
To book our dead and then to bury them,
To sort our nobles from our common men,
For many of our princes‚Äî woe the while!‚Äî
Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood.
So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs
In blood of princes, and the wounded steeds
Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage
Yerk out their arm√®d heels at their dead masters,
Killing them twice. O, give us leave, great king,
To view the field in safety and dispose
Of their dead bodies.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I tell thee truly, herald,
I know not if the day be ours or no,
For yet a many of your horsemen peer
And gallop o‚Äôer the field.

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: The day is yours.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!
What is this castle called that stands hard by?

sp.speaker: MONTJOY
sp.l: They call it Agincourt.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Then call we this the field of Agincourt,
Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Your grandfather of famous memory, an ‚Äôt
please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward
the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the
chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in
France.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: They did, Fluellen.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Your Majesty says very true. If your Majesties
is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good
service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing
leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, your Majesty
know, to this hour is an honorable badge of the
service. And I do believe your Majesty takes no
scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy‚Äôs day.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I wear it for a memorable honor,
For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
All the water in Wye cannot wash your
Majesty‚Äôs Welsh plood out of your pody, I can tell
you that. God pless it and preserve it as long as it
pleases his Grace and his Majesty too.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Thanks, good my countryman.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
By Jeshu, I am your Majesty‚Äôs countryman,
I care not who know it. I will confess it to all the
‚Äôorld. I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty,
praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an
honest man.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: God keep me so.‚Äî Our heralds, go with him.
Bring me just notice of the numbers dead
On both our parts.
sp.stage: Montjoy, English Heralds, and Gower exit.
sp.l: Call yonder fellow hither.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.p: Soldier, you must come to the King.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Soldier, why wear‚Äôst thou that glove in thy
cap?

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
An ‚Äôt please your Majesty, ‚Äôtis the gage of
one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: An Englishman?

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
An ‚Äôt please your Majesty, a rascal that
swaggered with me last night, who, if alive and ever
dare to challenge this glove, I have sworn to take
him a box o‚Äô th‚Äô ear, or if I can see my glove in his
cap, which he swore, as he was a soldier, he would
wear if alive, I will strike it out soundly.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
What think you, Captain Fluellen, is it fit
this soldier keep his oath?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
He is a craven and a villain else, an ‚Äôt
please your Majesty, in my conscience.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
It may be his enemy is a gentleman of
great sort, quite from the answer of his degree.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Though he be as good a gentleman as the
devil is, as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself, it is
necessary, look your Grace, that he keep his vow
and his oath. If he be perjured, see you now, his
reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jack Sauce as
ever his black shoe trod upon God‚Äôs ground and His
earth, in my conscience, la.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou
meet‚Äôst the fellow.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: So I will, my liege, as I live.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Who serv‚Äôst thou under?

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge
and literatured in the wars.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Call him hither to me, soldier.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: I will, my liege.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Here,
Fluellen, wear thou this favor for me, and stick it in
thy cap. When Alen√ßon and myself were down
together, I plucked this glove from his helm. If any
man challenge this, he is a friend to Alen√ßon and an
enemy to our person. If thou encounter any such,
apprehend him, an thou dost me love.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.stage: , putting the glove in his cap
sp.p:
Your Grace
does me as great honors as can be desired in the
hearts of his subjects. I would fain see the man that
has but two legs that shall find himself aggriefed at
this glove, that is all; but I would fain see it once, an
please God of His grace that I might see.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Know‚Äôst thou Gower?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: He is my dear friend, an please you.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to
my tent.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: I will fetch him.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester,
Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.
The glove which I have given him for a favor
May haply purchase him a box o‚Äô th‚Äô ear.
It is the soldier‚Äôs. I by bargain should
Wear it myself. Follow, good cousin Warwick.
If that the soldier strike him, as I judge
By his blunt bearing he will keep his word,
Some sudden mischief may arise of it,
For I do know Fluellen valiant
And, touched with choler, hot as gunpowder,
And quickly will return an injury.
Follow, and see there be no harm between them.‚Äî
Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: I warrant it is to knight you, captain.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
God‚Äôs will and His pleasure,
captain, I beseech you now, come apace to the
King. There is more good toward you peradventure
than is in your knowledge to dream of.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.stage: , to Fluellen, pointing to the glove in his own hat
sp.p: Sir, know you this glove?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: Know the glove? I know the glove is a glove.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: I know this, and thus I challenge it.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
‚ÄôSblood, an arrant traitor as any ‚Äôs in the
universal world, or in France, or in England!

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: How now, sir? You villain!

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: Do you think I‚Äôll be forsworn?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Stand away, Captain Gower. I will give treason
his payment into plows, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: I am no traitor.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
That‚Äôs a lie in thy throat.‚Äî I charge you in
his Majesty‚Äôs name, apprehend him. He‚Äôs a friend
of the Duke Alen√ßon‚Äôs.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.p: How now, how now, what‚Äôs the matter?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be
God for it, a most contagious treason come to
light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer‚Äôs
day.
sp.stage: Enter King of England and Exeter.
sp.p: Here is his Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: How now, what‚Äôs the matter?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that,
look your Grace, has struck the glove which your
Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alen√ßon.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow
of it. And he that I gave it to in change promised to
wear it in his cap. I promised to strike him if he did.
I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have
been as good as my word.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty‚Äôs
manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly,
lousy knave it is. I hope your Majesty is pear me
testimony and witness and will avouchment that
this is the glove of Alen√ßon that your Majesty is give
me, in your conscience now.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Give me thy glove, soldier.
Look, here is the fellow of it.
sp.l: ‚ÄôTwas I indeed thou promised‚Äôst to strike,
And thou hast given me most bitter terms.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
An please your Majesty, let his neck answer
for it, if there is any martial law in the world.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
How canst thou make me
satisfaction?

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
All offenses, my lord, come from the heart.
Never came any from mine that might offend your
Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: It was ourself thou didst abuse.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p:
Your Majesty came not like yourself. You
appeared to me but as a common man; witness the
night, your garments, your lowliness. And what
your Highness suffered under that shape, I beseech
you take it for your own fault and not mine, for, had
you been as I took you for, I made no offense.
Therefore, I beseech your Highness pardon me.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Here, uncle Exeter, fill this glove with crowns
And give it to this fellow.‚Äî Keep it, fellow,
And wear it for an honor in thy cap
Till I do challenge it.‚Äî Give him the crowns.‚Äî
And, captain, you must needs be friends with him.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
By this day and this light, the fellow has
mettle enough in his belly.‚Äî Hold, there is twelvepence
for you, and I pray you to serve God and keep
you out of prawls and prabbles and quarrels and
dissensions, and I warrant you it is the better for
you.

sp.speaker: WILLIAMS
sp.p: I will none of your money.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
It is with a good will. I can tell you it will
serve you to mend your shoes. Come, wherefore
should you be so pashful? Your shoes is not so
good. ‚ÄôTis a good silling, I warrant you, or I will
change it.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Now, herald, are the dead numbered?

sp.speaker: HERALD
sp.l: Here is the number of the slaughtered French.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Charles, Duke of Orl√©ans, nephew to the King;
John, Duke of Bourbon, and Lord Bouciqualt.
Of other lords and barons, knights and squires,
Full fifteen hundred, besides common men.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French
That in the field lie slain. Of princes in this number
And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead
One hundred twenty-six. Added to these,
Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen,
Eight thousand and four hundred, of the which
Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights.
So that in these ten thousand they have lost,
There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.
The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires,
And gentlemen of blood and quality.
The names of those their nobles that lie dead:
Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France;
Jacques of Chatillon, Admiral of France;
The Master of the Crossbows, Lord Rambures;
Great Master of France, the brave Sir Guichard Dauphin;
John, Duke of Alen√ßon; Anthony, Duke of Brabant,
The brother to the Duke of Burgundy;
And Edward, Duke of Bar. Of lusty earls:
Grandpr√© and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix,
Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.
Here was a royal fellowship of death.
Where is the number of our English dead?
Edward the Duke of York, the Earl of Suffolk,
Sir Richard Ketly, Davy Gam, esquire;
None else of name, and of all other men
But five and twenty. O God, thy arm was here,
And not to us, but to thy arm alone
Ascribe we all! When, without stratagem,
But in plain shock and even play of battle,
Was ever known so great and little loss
On one part and on th‚Äô other? Take it, God,
For it is none but thine.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: ‚ÄôTis wonderful.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Come, go we in procession to the village,
And be it death proclaim√®d through our host
To boast of this or take that praise from God
Which is His only.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Is it not lawful, an please your Majesty, to
tell how many is killed?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Yes, captain, but with this acknowledgment:
That God fought for us.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: Yes, my conscience, He did us great good.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Do we all holy rites.
Let there be sung Non nobis, and Te Deum,
The dead with charity enclosed in clay,
And then to Calais, and to England then,
Where ne‚Äôer from France arrived more happy men.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story
That I may prompt them; and of such as have,
I humbly pray them to admit th‚Äô excuse
Of time, of numbers, and due course of things,
Which cannot in their huge and proper life
Be here presented. Now we bear the King
Toward Calais. Grant him there. There seen,
Heave him away upon your wing√®d thoughts
Athwart the sea. Behold, the English beach
Pales in the flood with men, wives, and boys,
Whose shouts and claps outvoice the deep-mouthed sea,
Which, like a mighty whiffler ‚Äôfore the King
Seems to prepare his way. So let him land,
And solemnly see him set on to London.
So swift a pace hath thought that even now
You may imagine him upon Blackheath,
Where that his lords desire him to have borne
His bruis√®d helmet and his bended sword
Before him through the city. He forbids it,
Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride,
Giving full trophy, signal, and ostent
Quite from himself, to God. But now behold,
In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought,
How London doth pour out her citizens.
The Mayor and all his brethren in best sort,
Like to the senators of th‚Äô antique Rome,
With the plebeians swarming at their heels,
Go forth and fetch their conqu‚Äôring Caesar in‚Äî
As, by a lower but by loving likelihood
Were now the general of our gracious empress,
As in good time he may, from Ireland coming,
Bringing rebellion broach√®d on his sword,
How many would the peaceful city quit
To welcome him! Much more, and much more cause,
Did they this Harry. Now in London place him
( As yet the lamentation of the French
Invites the King of England‚Äôs stay at home;
The Emperor‚Äôs coming in behalf of France
To order peace between them) and omit
All the occurrences, whatever chanced,
Till Harry‚Äôs back return again to France.
There must we bring him, and myself have played
The interim, by remembering you ‚Äôtis past.
Then brook abridgment, and your eyes advance
After your thoughts, straight back again to France.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
Nay, that‚Äôs right. But why wear you your leek
today? Saint Davy‚Äôs day is past.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
There is occasions and causes why and
wherefore in all things. I will tell you ass my
friend, Captain Gower. The rascally, scald, beggarly,
lousy, pragging knave Pistol, which you and
yourself and all the world know to be no petter than
a fellow, look you now, of no merits, he is come to
me and prings me pread and salt yesterday, look
you, and bid me eat my leek. It was in a place where
I could not breed no contention with him, but I will
be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once
again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my
desires.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
Why here he comes, swelling like a
turkey-cock.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
‚ÄôTis no matter for his swellings, nor his
turkey-cocks.‚Äî God pless you, Aunchient Pistol,
you scurvy, lousy knave, God pless you.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Ha, art thou bedlam? Dost thou thirst, base
Trojan, to have me fold up Parca‚Äôs fatal web? Hence.
I am qualmish at the smell of leek.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave,
at my desires and my requests and my petitions, to
eat, look you, this leek. Because, look you, you do
not love it, nor your affections and your appetites
and your disgestions does not agree with it, I would
desire you to eat it.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p: There is one goat for you.

Will you be so good, scald knave,
as eat it?

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Base Trojan, thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
You say very true, scald knave, when God‚Äôs
will is. I will desire you to live in the meantime and
eat your victuals. Come, there is sauce for it.

You called me yesterday ‚Äú mountain squire,‚Äù
but I will make you today a squire of low degree. I
pray you, fall to. If you can mock a leek, you can eat
a leek.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p: Enough, captain. You have astonished him.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
I say I will make him eat some part of my
leek, or I will peat his pate four days.‚Äî Bite, I pray
you. It is good for your green wound and your
ploody coxcomb.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Must I bite?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of
question, too, and ambiguities.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
By this leek, I will most horribly revenge.
Fluellen threatens him. I eat and eat, I swear‚Äî

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Eat, I pray you. Will you have some more
sauce to your leek? There is not enough leek to
swear by.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Quiet thy cudgel. Thou dost see I eat.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Much good do you, scald knave, heartily.
Nay, pray you throw none away. The skin is good for
your broken coxcomb. When you take occ√°sions to
see leeks hereafter, I pray you mock at ‚Äôem, that is
all.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Ay, leeks is good. Hold you, there is a groat
to heal your pate.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Me, a groat?

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
Yes, verily, and in truth you shall take it, or I
have another leek in my pocket, which you shall
eat.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: I take thy groat in earnest of revenge.

sp.speaker: FLUELLEN
sp.p:
If I owe you anything, I will pay you in
cudgels. You shall be a woodmonger and buy
nothing of me but cudgels. God be wi‚Äô you and
keep you and heal your pate.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: All hell shall stir for this.

sp.speaker: GOWER
sp.p:
Go, go. You are a counterfeit cowardly knave.
Will you mock at an ancient tradition begun upon
an honorable respect and worn as a memorable
trophy of predeceased valor, and dare not avouch in
your deeds any of your words? I have seen you
gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or
thrice. You thought because he could not speak
English in the native garb, he could not therefore
handle an English cudgel. You find it otherwise, and
henceforth let a Welsh correction teach you a good
English condition. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?
News have I that my Doll is dead i‚Äô th‚Äô spital of a
malady of France, and there my rendezvous is quite
cut off. Old I do wax, and from my weary limbs
honor is cudgeled. Well, bawd I‚Äôll turn, and something
lean to cutpurse of quick hand. To England
will I steal, and there I‚Äôll steal.
sp.l: And patches will I get unto these cudgeled scars,
And swear I got them in the Gallia wars.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter at one door, King Henry, Exeter, Bedford, Warwick, Westmoreland, and other Lords. At another, Queen Isabel of France, the King of France, the Princess Katherine and Alice, the Duke of Burgundy, and other French.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Peace to this meeting wherefor we are met.
Unto our brother France and to our sister,
Health and fair time of day.‚Äî Joy and good wishes
To our most fair and princely cousin Katherine.‚Äî
And, as a branch and member of this royalty,
By whom this great assembly is contrived,
We do salute you, Duke of Burgundy.‚Äî
And princes French, and peers, health to you all.

sp.speaker: KING OF FRANCE
sp.l: Right joyous are we to behold your face,
Most worthy brother England. Fairly met.‚Äî
So are you, princes English, every one.

sp.speaker: QUEEN OF FRANCE
sp.l: So happy be the issue, brother Ireland,
Of this good day and of this gracious meeting,
As we are now glad to behold your eyes‚Äî
Your eyes which hitherto have borne in them
Against the French that met them in their bent
The fatal balls of murdering basilisks.
The venom of such looks, we fairly hope,
Have lost their quality, and that this day
Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: To cry ‚Äú Amen‚Äù to that, thus we appear.

sp.speaker: QUEEN OF FRANCE
sp.l: You English princes all, I do salute you.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: My duty to you both, on equal love,
Great kings of France and England. That I have labored
With all my wits, my pains, and strong endeavors
To bring your most imperial Majesties
Unto this bar and royal interview,
Your Mightiness on both parts best can witness.
Since, then, my office hath so far prevailed
That face to face and royal eye to eye
You have congreeted, let it not disgrace me
If I demand before this royal view
What rub or what impediment there is
Why that the naked, poor, and mangled peace,
Dear nurse of arts, plenties, and joyful births,
Should not in this best garden of the world,
Our fertile France, put up her lovely visage?
Alas, she hath from France too long been chased,
And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps,
Corrupting in its own fertility.
Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart,
Unprun√®d, dies. Her hedges, even-pleached,
Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair,
Put forth disordered twigs. Her fallow leas
The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory
Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts
That should deracinate such savagery.
The even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth
The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover,
Wanting the scythe, withal uncorrected, rank,
Conceives by idleness, and nothing teems
But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burrs,
Losing both beauty and utility.
And all our vineyards, fallows, meads, and hedges,
Defective in their natures, grow to wildness.
Even so our houses and ourselves and children
Have lost, or do not learn for want of time,
The sciences that should become our country,
But grow like savages, as soldiers will
That nothing do but meditate on blood,
To swearing and stern looks, diffused attire,
And everything that seems unnatural.
Which to reduce into our former favor
You are assembled, and my speech entreats
That I may know the let why gentle peace
Should not expel these inconveniences
And bless us with her former qualities.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace,
Whose want gives growth to th‚Äô imperfections
Which you have cited, you must buy that peace
With full accord to all our just demands,
Whose tenors and particular effects
You have, enscheduled briefly, in your hands.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: The King hath heard them, to the which as yet
There is no answer made.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Well then, the peace which you before so urged
Lies in his answer.

sp.speaker: KING OF FRANCE
sp.l: I have but with a cursitory eye
O‚Äôerglanced the articles. Pleaseth your Grace
To appoint some of your council presently
To sit with us once more with better heed
To resurvey them, we will suddenly
Pass our accept and peremptory answer.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Brother, we shall.‚Äî Go, uncle Exeter,
And brother Clarence, and you, brother Gloucester,
Warwick, and Huntington, go with the King,
And take with you free power to ratify,
Augment, or alter, as your wisdoms best
Shall see advantageable for our dignity,
Anything in or out of our demands,
And we‚Äôll consign thereto.‚Äî Will you, fair sister,
Go with the princes or stay here with us?

sp.speaker: QUEEN OF FRANCE
sp.l: Our gracious brother, I will go with them.
Haply a woman‚Äôs voice may do some good
When articles too nicely urged be stood on.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us.
She is our capital demand, comprised
Within the forerank of our articles.

sp.speaker: QUEEN OF FRANCE
sp.l: She hath good leave.

div.stage: All but Katherine, and the King of England, and Alice exit.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Fair Katherine, and most fair,
Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms
Such as will enter at a lady‚Äôs ear
And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Your Majesty shall mock at me. I cannot
speak your England.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
O fair Katherine, if you will love me
soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to
hear you confess it brokenly with your English
tongue. Do you like me, Kate?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell wat is ‚Äú like
me.‚Äù

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
An angel is like you, Kate, and you are
like an angel.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Que dit-il? Que je suis semblable √†
les anges?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oui, vraiment, sauf votre Gr√¢ce, ainsi dit-il.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
I said so, dear Katherine, and I must not
blush to affirm it.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
√î bon Dieu, les langues des hommes sont
pleines de tromperies.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
What says she, fair one? That the
tongues of men are full of deceits?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p:
Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of
deceits; dat is de Princess.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
The Princess is the better Englishwoman.‚Äî
I‚Äô faith, Kate, my wooing is fit for thy
understanding. I am glad thou canst speak no
better English, for if thou couldst, thou wouldst
find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I
had sold my farm to buy my crown. I know no ways
to mince it in love, but directly to say ‚Äú I love you.‚Äù
Then if you urge me farther than to say ‚Äú Do you, in
faith?‚Äù I wear out my suit. Give me your answer, i‚Äô
faith, do; and so clap hands and a bargain. How say
you, lady?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: Sauf votre honneur, me understand well.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Marry, if you would put me to verses or
to dance for your sake, Kate, why you undid me.
For the one, I have neither words nor measure; and
for the other, I have no strength in measure, yet a
reasonable measure in strength. If I could win a
lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with
my armor on my back, under the correction of
bragging be it spoken, I should quickly leap into a
wife. Or if I might buffet for my love, or bound my
horse for her favors, I could lay on like a butcher
and sit like a jackanapes, never off. But, before God,
Kate, I cannot look greenly nor gasp out my eloquence,
nor I have no cunning in protestation, only
downright oaths, which I never use till urged, nor
never break for urging. If thou canst love a fellow of
this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth sun-burning,
that never looks in his glass for love of
anything he sees there, let thine eye be thy cook. I
speak to thee plain soldier. If thou canst love me for
this, take me. If not, to say to thee that I shall die is
true, but for thy love, by the Lord, no. Yet I love thee
too. And while thou liv‚Äôst, dear Kate, take a fellow of
plain and uncoined constancy, for he perforce must
do thee right because he hath not the gift to woo in
other places. For these fellows of infinite tongue,
that can rhyme themselves into ladies‚Äô favors, they
do always reason themselves out again. What? A
speaker is but a prater, a rhyme is but a ballad, a
good leg will fall, a straight back will stoop, a black
beard will turn white, a curled pate will grow bald,
a fair face will wither, a full eye will wax hollow, but
a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or
rather the sun and not the moon, for it shines bright
and never changes but keeps his course truly. If
thou would have such a one, take me. And take me,
take a soldier. Take a soldier, take a king. And what
say‚Äôst thou then to my love? Speak, my fair, and
fairly, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of
France?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
No, it is not possible you should love the
enemy of France, Kate. But, in loving me, you
should love the friend of France, for I love France
so well that I will not part with a village of it. I will
have it all mine. And, Kate, when France is mine
and I am yours, then yours is France and you are
mine.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: I cannot tell wat is dat.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
No, Kate? I will tell thee in French,
which I am sure will hang upon my tongue like a
new-married wife about her husband‚Äôs neck, hardly
to be shook off. Je quand sur le possession de
France, et quand vous avez le possession de moi‚Äî let
me see, what then? Saint Denis be my speed!‚Äî donc
v√¥tre est France, et vous √™tes mienne. It is as easy for
me, Kate, to conquer the kingdom as to speak so
much more French. I shall never move thee in
French, unless it be to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Sauf votre honneur, le fran√ßais que vous
parlez, il est meilleur que l‚Äôanglais lequel je parle.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
No, faith, is ‚Äôt not, Kate, but thy speaking
of my tongue, and I thine, most truly-falsely must
needs be granted to be much at one. But, Kate, dost
thou understand thus much English? Canst thou
love me?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate? I‚Äôll
ask them. Come, I know thou lovest me; and at
night, when you come into your closet, you‚Äôll question
this gentlewoman about me, and, I know, Kate,
you will, to her, dispraise those parts in me that you
love with your heart. But, good Kate, mock me
mercifully, the rather, gentle princess, because I
love thee cruelly. If ever thou beest mine, Kate, as I
have a saving faith within me tells me thou shalt, I
get thee with scambling, and thou must therefore
needs prove a good soldier-breeder. Shall not thou
and I, between Saint Denis and Saint George, compound
a boy, half French, half English, that shall go
to Constantinople and take the Turk by the beard?
Shall we not? What say‚Äôst thou, my fair flower de
luce?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: I do not know dat.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
No, ‚Äôtis hereafter to know, but now to
promise. Do but now promise, Kate, you will
endeavor for your French part of such a boy; and
for my English moiety, take the word of a king and
a bachelor. How answer you, la plus belle Katherine
du monde, mon tr√®s cher et divin d√©esse?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Your Majest√© ‚Äôave fausse French enough to
deceive de most sage demoiselle dat is en France.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Now fie upon my false French. By mine
honor, in true English, I love thee, Kate. By which
honor I dare not swear thou lovest me, yet my blood
begins to flatter me that thou dost, notwithstanding
the poor and untempering effect of my visage. Now
beshrew my father‚Äôs ambition! He was thinking of
civil wars when he got me; therefore was I created
with a stubborn outside, with an aspect of iron, that
when I come to woo ladies, I fright them. But, in
faith, Kate, the elder I wax, the better I shall appear.
My comfort is that old age, that ill layer-up of
beauty, can do no more spoil upon my face. Thou
hast me, if thou hast me, at the worst, and thou shalt
wear me, if thou wear me, better and better. And
therefore tell me, most fair Katherine, will you have
me? Put off your maiden blushes, avouch the
thoughts of your heart with the looks of an empress,
take me by the hand, and say ‚Äú Harry of England, I
am thine,‚Äù which word thou shalt no sooner bless
mine ear withal, but I will tell thee aloud ‚Äú England
is thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Henry
Plantagenet is thine,‚Äù who, though I speak it before
his face, if he be not fellow with the best king, thou
shalt find the best king of good fellows. Come, your
answer in broken music, for thy voice is music, and
thy English broken. Therefore, queen of all, Katherine,
break thy mind to me in broken English. Wilt
thou have me?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: Dat is as it shall please de roi mon p√®re.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Nay, it will please him well, Kate; it shall
please him, Kate.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: Den it sall also content me.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you
my queen.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Laissez, mon seigneur, laissez, laissez! Ma
foi, je ne veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur,
en baisant la main d‚Äô une‚Äî Notre Seigneur!‚Äî
indigne serviteur. Excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon
tr√®s puissant seigneur.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p:
Les dames et demoiselles, pour √™tre bais√©es
devant leurs noces, il n‚Äôest pas la coutume de France.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: Madam my interpreter, what says she?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p:
Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of
France‚Äî I cannot tell wat is baiser en Anglish.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p: To kiss.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Your Majest√© entendre bettre que moi.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
It is not a fashion for the maids in France
to kiss before they are married, would she say?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oui, vraiment.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great
kings. Dear Kate, you and I cannot be confined
within the weak list of a country‚Äôs fashion. We are
the makers of manners, Kate, and the liberty that
follows our places stops the mouth of all find-faults,
as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of
your country in denying me a kiss. Therefore,
patiently and yielding. He kisses her. You have
witchcraft in your lips, Kate. There is more eloquence
in a sugar touch of them than in the tongues
of the French council, and they should sooner
persuade Harry of England than a general petition
of monarchs.
sp.stage: Enter the French power, the French King and Queen and Burgundy, and the English Lords Westmoreland and Exeter.
sp.p: Here comes your father.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.p:
God save your Majesty. My royal cousin,
teach you our princess English?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
I would have her learn, my fair cousin,
how perfectly I love her, and that is good English.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.p: Is she not apt?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.p:
Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition
is not smooth, so that, having neither the voice
nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so
conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will
appear in his true likeness.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.p:
Pardon the frankness of my mirth if I
answer you for that. If you would conjure in her,
